p: Ethyl acetate fractions (EA) from A. conyzoides, T. erecta, C. morifolium, and T. officinale showed activities against S. aureus. It is worth noting that EA from A. conyzoides and T. erecta displayed considerable impacts on Gram-negative bacteria including E. coli, K. pneumoniae (for A. conyzoides), and P. aeruginosa (for T. erecta). However, evaluating these EA on uropathogenic isolates revealed that merely the EA of Ageratum conyzoides expressed the capacity against uropathogenic isolates. Particularly, it was active against E. coli and K. pneumoniae producing ESBL, the strains that were highly resistant in clinical infection. Hence, Ageratum conyzoides is a good candidate for antiuropathogenic bacteria.
